head.title: To Nurture the Worker, and the Child

hedline.hl1: To Nurture the Worker, and the Child

abstract.p: Daniel B Rubock letter recalls making difficult but satisfying decision to give up money and prestige of law partnership for sake of his family's happiness (S)

block.p: My own life choice belies a Sept. 6 letter writer's assertion that men rarely have to make the ''hard choice'' between ''work or family'' to become, for instance, a partner at a law firm. Years ago, as a veteran of some major Wall Street law firms, I made a very difficult and ultimately very satisfying decision to forgo the money, prestige and the sacrifice of family time that come with making partner.

My own life choice belies a Sept. 6 letter writer's assertion that men rarely have to make the ''hard choice'' between ''work or family'' to become, for instance, a partner at a law firm. Years ago, as a veteran of some major Wall Street law firms, I made a very difficult and ultimately very satisfying decision to forgo the money, prestige and the sacrifice of family time that come with making partner.
I am far from alone among my male lawyer colleagues in having made such a choice. But in my view, I had to make that choice for my own, and my family's, happiness.
DANIEL B. RUBOCK Pelham, N.Y., Sept. 6, 2000
